dn2.title: The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

dn10.title: With Subha
dn10.heading: Sīla, Samādhi, Paññā
dn10.description: The Buddha taught, praised, and encouraged the three noble aggregates—sīla, samādhi, and paññā—each serving as a necessary foundation for the development of the next.

mn2.title: All the Influxes
mn2.heading: Gateway to the Dhamma
mn2.description: The realization of the Dhamma is for one who, having understood yoniso manasikāra, gives up seven kinds of influxes.

mn11.title: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

mn12.title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

mn13.title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

mn14.title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

mn16.title: Obstinacies
mn16.heading: Impediments to Progress
mn16.description: A trainee needs to abandon ten impediments to achieve maturity in the Dhamma. With this foundation, they can develop right composure (samādhi).

mn18.title: The Lump of Honey
mn18.heading: Beyond All Thoughts
mn18.description: If one abandons delight in that because of which perceptions arise—the sense organs and their counterparts—then one will be free from defilements even amidst those perceptions. This, and not focusing on one object, is also how “proliferation” (papañca) is abandoned.

mn19.title: Two Kinds of Thought
mn19.heading: Renunciation -> Jhāna
mn19.description: Fostering the context of danger and harm of unbeneficial thoughts—of sensuality, ill will, and cruelty—and by doing so inclining the mind in the opposite direction, is how one develops jhāna.

mn22.title: The Simile of the Venomous Snake
mn22.heading: A Pernicious View
mn22.description: The Buddha strongly disparages the view that one can engage in such acts of sensual nature—chiefly sexual activity—without hindering progress on the path. He calls this view “pernicious” and, amidst an assembly of monks, intensely rebukes a monk who stubbornly adhered to it, causing him great embarrassment.

mn24.title: The Relay Chariots
mn24.heading: Stages of Purification
mn24.description: The path to Nibbāna progresses through successive stages of purification, each laying the foundation for the next, ultimately leading to the total cessation of assumption.

mn27.title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

mn28.title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

mn29.title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

mn30.title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

mn33.title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

mn34.title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

mn37.title: The Shorter Discourse on the Destruction of Craving

mn38.title: The Longer Discourse on the Destruction of Craving
mn38.heading: Dependent Origination
mn38.description: Dependent origination is not a temporal sequence of causes and effect but the discernment of a simultaneous interdependence of two phenomena in the present experience. It's about knowing the uncontrollable underlying foundation of one's experience while it is enduring so appropriation in regard to anything within it ceases.

mn39.title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura
mn39.heading: Stages of Training
mn39.description: One seeking to be a true ascetic and to realize the goal of the ascetic life must undertake the training laid down by the Buddha and progress through its various stages, never resting content with what has already been achieved.

mn53.title: A Trainee
mn53.heading: Qualities of a Trainee
mn53.description: To qualify as a “practicing trainee,” a noble disciple must possess various qualities, all of which are on the side of renunciation.

mn57.title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

mn61.title: Advice to Venerable Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika
mn61.heading: Checking Your Actions
mn61.description: The purification of one's physical, verbal, and mental actions is done by repeatedly inspecting whether they are beneficial before, while, and after performing them; and acting accordingly.

mn62.title: The Longer Advice to Venerable Rāhula

mn107.title: With Moggallāna the Accountant
mn107.heading: The Gradual Training
mn107.description: The exposition of the gradual training, outlining a certain order of practice to achieve Nibbāna. Each stage addresses increasingly subtle defilements, which can only be recognized and properly dealt with once the coarser ones have been addressed. Disregarding this order is likely to lead one astray.

sn1.1.title: Crossing the Flood
sn1.1.heading: The Middle Way (Not “Moderation”)
sn1.1.description: The Middle Way does not lie in “moderation” but in neither indulgence nor denial, transcending these limited perspectives of an ordinary person.

sn12.67.title: Bundles of Reeds
sn12.67.heading: Dependent Origination
sn12.67.description: An exposition of dependent origination underlining how this principle does not describe a process across multiple lifetimes nor an complex sequence of “mind moments” in the present, but rather the simultaneous interdependence of two phenomena right here and now. Seeing this interdependence is how the entire mass of suffering ceases, and the right dispassion, rooted in understanding, is achieved.

sn35.94.title: Untamed, Unguarded
sn35.94.heading: Restraining the Senses
sn35.94.description: One wanting to put an end to suffering must guard and restrain their senses. Not inclining towards the pleasant and away from the unpleasant, not proliferating over these aspects of perception, one trains to remain unwavering in the face of pressure.

sn40.1.title: A Question About the First jhāna

sn45.55.title: Accomplishment in attention in light of the origin (1st)

an5.24.title: Unvirtuous
an5.24.heading: Vital Conditions for Liberation
an5.24.description: The path to liberation relies on distinct conditions, each establishing the foundation for the next, beginning with the cultivation of virtue.

an5.114.title: At Andhakavinda
an5.114.heading: Advice for Beginners
an5.114.description: The Buddha encouraged beginners to establish themselves in five principles, none related to “meditation instructions” in the modern sense.
